Posts.Content: crisp72469 wrote: Hi - I am a single, active 39 year old and had my first mammogram on 10/17/08.  After a second mamogram and a biopsy --- on 10/27/08, I was diagnosed with DCIS on my left breast.  I have no family history of breast and ovarian cancer, positive on ER/PR receptor, and unlikely to test positve for the BRCA1 gene (based on consultaion with the Genetics' Dept).  I met with my surgeon on 10/29/08 and she suggested mastectomy on the left breast due to the "spread" of micro-calcifications on the upper-outer quadrant of the left breast.  My size is 34b, and I feel and believe that a mastectomy on the left breast is warranted.  Right breast also showed some micro-calcifications, although they don't seem to pose any concern at this time.  Now, I am contemplating a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction, because: (1) I just want to continue living my life and not worry about the right breast contracting cancer, and (2) I am fairly young and symmetrical breast size matters to me.  My plastic surgeon wants me to rethink my decision about doing a mastectoy on my right breast since she believes my decision was done on "panic mode," and another surgeon says that my decision to do a bilateral is reasonable, but medically un-necessary.  I would like to hear what others have done in similar cases.  My surgery is scheduled for 11/26/08 (day before Thanksgiving).  Thank you for your input in advance. Best regards, Cristina Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 05:29PM crisp72469 wrote: Dear Lauren, Thank you for your response.  My decision to do a bilateral mastecomy was pretty much final, until I met with my plastic surgeon and another surgeon for a second opinion; then I started having second thoughts.  This is a life-changing decision and it is never easy.  Everything happened so fast, and all I wanted now is to make sure that I am making a sensible and logical decision.  Although there is no wrong answer in this case, my decision should be based on what is best for me going forward.  Having peace of mind and knowing that the risk to contract BC again will significally be reduced, will help me live a life of quality. Thank you for sharing your experience.  I pray that you have a successful surgery, as well as a swift recovery.  Take care and God bless.  I will check up on you from time to time. Cristina
